The Johns Hopkins Rifle Club is
to ·sponsor inter-d:ass and intercompany shooting matches this year,
it was announced by Capt. F. P.
Coffin, of the Department of Military Tactics at the Johns Hopkins.

Fall Track Practice At Homewood

The team is picked flrom the
members of the Rifle Club. Last
·year's team, which showed great
ability in winning more than half
of its many matches, was made up
of the following men: Perkins,
president of the club; Hesser, manager; Stegman, Chancelor, Murback, Kahler, H. P. Johnson, W.
Glass, Hill, Jurak and Forsyth.
Stegman and Perkins, in particular,
distinguished themselves; Stegman,
member of the R. 0. T. C. team
for the Third Corps Area, won
several N. R. A. awards; Perkins
was a member of the civilian rifle
team from Maryland.
Activities will begin the first of
.November. Thirtymen have signed
up and more are expected. Members are assigned to instruction and
practice periods twice a week.

To Begin October 20; Will
Continue 6 Weeks
-Tlie Hopkins harriers, severely
handicapped by the loss of Walter
Glass for the remainder of the seasion, will fact .ie Ursinus College
cross country team of Collegeville,
Pa., tomorrow. Last year the Hop·
kinsmen defeated Ursinus at Homewood by a score of 26 to 29. Sutin,
an Ursinus veteran who won one
race in the Hopkins meet last year,
will again compete against the Jays.
Although the harriers suffered a
one-sided defeat in the hands of
Virginia last week, they were impeded considerably by the short
practice season and the length of
the trip to Virginia. All this week
the team has been gradually working the course up from 3.5 miles to
5 miles for tomorrow's meet.
The regular fall track practice
will be held beginning October 30,
on every Tuesday and Thursday
and will continue for six weeks
throughout October and November.
These practices will be held expressly for the purpose of improving speed, the gaining of endurance,
and the perfecting of the coordination of the muscles. It is especially
essential that middle distance men
be out to practice .twice a week.
Pole vaulters, javelin throwers, as
well as sprinters and hurdlers who
report for strengthening will all
find this training period of invaluable aid.

Following the Hopkins-St. John's
football game tomorow, a tea dance
under the sponsorship of the Cotillon Board will · be held in Levering Hall. Arrangements have been
made to have Bob Lowry and his
Tornado Orchestra provide the
syncopation. The features which
usually characterize all the Cotillon
Board dances will find a prominent
place on the program.
As a special celebration of the
game, one of the most important of
the season, another dance is to be
held at the Hotel Belvedere in the
evening. Members of the Board
stated that one of the star actresses
in the cast of East Wind, playing at
Ford's this week, is to attend the
dance. Bob Iula will personally
conduct his ten-piece band throughO\!t the evening. Novelties and
other attractions will feature the
evening's entertainment.
The subscription price is $2. The
dancing will take place in the main
ballroom on the thirteenth floor of
the Belvedere.

How students of the Jo'hns
Hopkins ~ university comported
themselves a third of a century
ago is vividly recalled by a recent
gift to the University library. C.
C. Gaddess, a member of the
Class of 1899, kept a neat scrapbook in which he preserved newspaper clippings, invitations, official notices, and such mementoes
of his life as a Johns Hopkins
student. The alumnus died in
1901. The prized scrapbook was
presented to Dr. John C. French
last year by members of the late
man's family. Dr. French, head
librarian at Homewood, was also
a classmate of Mr. Gaddess.
The first clipping from The Sun
of June 10, 1899 records the fact
that some of the seniors were so
jubilant at having passed their examinations that they celebrated
by running their class flag of
green and white up on the signal
staff of the Weather Bureau, then
stationed at the University, with
the result that the telephone of
the Bureau was busy for a time
with inquiries from anxious citizens desiring to know what the
strange signal meant.
Mr. Gaddess kept a complete
newspaper record of his commencement, which was marked,
according to the Su:n, by "a brilliant audience and impressive exercises." According to the reporter, from opening to close it
was "one great scholastic and
social success." Degrees were
conferred on 108 candi9.ates. Only

The Johns Hopkins Rifle Club is
to ·sponsor inter-d:ass and intercompany shooting matches this year,
it was announced by Capt. F. P.
Coffin, of the Department of Military Tactics at the Johns Hopkins.

Fall Track Practice At Homewood

The team is picked flrom the
members of the Rifle Club. Last
·year's team, which showed great
ability in winning more than half
of its many matches, was made up
of the following men: Perkins,
president of the club; Hesser, manager; Stegman, Chancelor, Murback, Kahler, H. P. Johnson, W.
Glass, Hill, Jurak and Forsyth.
Stegman and Perkins, in particular,
distinguished themselves; Stegman,
member of the R. 0. T. C. team
for the Third Corps Area, won
several N. R. A. awards; Perkins
was a member of the civilian rifle
team from Maryland.
Activities will begin the first of
.November. Thirtymen have signed
up and more are expected. Members are assigned to instruction and
practice periods twice a week.

To Begin October 20; Will
Continue 6 Weeks
-Tlie Hopkins harriers, severely
handicapped by the loss of Walter
Glass for the remainder of the seasion, will fact .ie Ursinus College
cross country team of Collegeville,
Pa., tomorrow. Last year the Hop·
kinsmen defeated Ursinus at Homewood by a score of 26 to 29. Sutin,
an Ursinus veteran who won one
race in the Hopkins meet last year,
will again compete against the Jays.
Although the harriers suffered a
one-sided defeat in the hands of
Virginia last week, they were impeded considerably by the short
practice season and the length of
the trip to Virginia. All this week
the team has been gradually working the course up from 3.5 miles to
5 miles for tomorrow's meet.
The regular fall track practice
will be held beginning October 30,
on every Tuesday and Thursday
and will continue for six weeks
throughout October and November.
These practices will be held expressly for the purpose of improving speed, the gaining of endurance,
and the perfecting of the coordination of the muscles. It is especially
essential that middle distance men
be out to practice .twice a week.
Pole vaulters, javelin throwers, as
well as sprinters and hurdlers who
report for strengthening will all
find this training period of invaluable aid.

Following the Hopkins-St. John's
football game tomorow, a tea dance
under the sponsorship of the Cotillon Board will · be held in Levering Hall. Arrangements have been
made to have Bob Lowry and his
Tornado Orchestra provide the
syncopation. The features which
usually characterize all the Cotillon
Board dances will find a prominent
place on the program.
As a special celebration of the
game, one of the most important of
the season, another dance is to be
held at the Hotel Belvedere in the
evening. Members of the Board
stated that one of the star actresses
in the cast of East Wind, playing at
Ford's this week, is to attend the
dance. Bob Iula will personally
conduct his ten-piece band throughO\!t the evening. Novelties and
other attractions will feature the
evening's entertainment.
The subscription price is $2. The
dancing will take place in the main
ballroom on the thirteenth floor of
the Belvedere.

How "Students In Gay 90's

Scrapbook Of Hopkins Events, Kept By C. C. Gaddess,
Class Of 1899, Presented To
Dr. French
How students of the Jo'hns
Hopkins ~ university comported
themselves a third of a century
ago is vividly recalled by a recent
gift to the University library. C.
C. Gaddess, a member of the
Class of 1899, kept a neat scrapbook in which he preserved newspaper clippings, invitations, official notices, and such mementoes
of his life as a Johns Hopkins
student. The alumnus died in
1901. The prized scrapbook was
presented to Dr. John C. French
last year by members of the late
man's family. Dr. French, head
librarian at Homewood, was also
a classmate of Mr. Gaddess.
The first clipping from The Sun
of June 10, 1899 records the fact
that some of the seniors were so
jubilant at having passed their examinations that they celebrated
by running their class flag of
green and white up on the signal
staff of the Weather Bureau, then
stationed at the University, with
the result that the telephone of
the Bureau was busy for a time
with inquiries from anxious citizens desiring to know what the
strange signal meant.
Mr. Gaddess kept a complete
newspaper record of his commencement, which was marked,
according to the Su:n, by "a brilliant audience and impressive exercises." According to the reporter, from opening to close it
was "one great scholastic and
social success." Degrees were
conferred on 108 candi9.ates. Only
